segments.label: Pre-Dynastic Period
segments.note: Transformation of Nile Valley communities; regional cultures, emergent elites, proto-writing and iconography.

segments.label: Early Dynastic Period
segments.note: Unification of Upper and Lower Egypt; royal titulary crystallizes; Memphis as political center.

segments.label: Old Kingdom
segments.note: First ‘golden age’; pyramid complexes; centralized kingship and state institutions.

segments.label: First Intermediate Period
segments.note: Decentralization and rival houses; regional artistic and textual diversity.

segments.label: Middle Kingdom
segments.note: Theban reunification; administrative reforms; classical literature and refined ideology of kingship.

segments.label: Second Intermediate Period
segments.note: Hyksos and multi-polar rule; military and technological transfers (e.g., chariot, composite bow).

segments.label: New Kingdom
segments.note: Imperial apex; expansion into Levant and Nubia; monumental temples; international diplomacy.

segments.label: Third Intermediate Period
segments.note: Divided authority (Tanis, Thebes, Libyan/Nubian lines); sacral kingship and regionalization.

segments.label: Late Period
segments.note: Saite renaissance; recurrent foreign interventions (Assyrian, Persian); resilient Egyptian culture pre-Hellenistic era.

segments.label: Ubaid Period
segments.note: Village culture, irrigation, Eridu temples; foundations of urban life.

segments.label: Uruk Period
segments.note: Rise of Uruk as first true city; proto-writing, monumental temples.

segments.label: Jemdet Nasr Period
segments.note: Short transitional era; early writing and administrative expansion.

segments.label: Early Dynastic Period
segments.note: Sumerian city-states; early kingship, conflict, and literature.

segments.label: Akkadian Empire
segments.note: First empire under Sargon; Semitic dominance; collapse after 180 years.

segments.label: Gutian Domination
segments.note: Instability under Gutian rule; interregnum following Akkadian fall.

segments.label: Ur III Period
segments.note: Neo-Sumerian revival; centralized state; flourishing literature and law.

segments.label: Isin-Larsa and Old Babylonian
segments.note: Amorite dynasties; rivalry of Isin and Larsa; Hammurabi’s Babylonian unification; fall to Hittites.

segments.label: Kassite, Middle Babylonian & Middle Assyrian
segments.note: Kassite stability; Babylonian fragmentation; Assyria’s rise as militarized state; regional diplomacy.

segments.label: Neo-Assyrian Empire
segments.note: Imperial apex; provincial system, mass deportations; Nineveh and Ashurbanipal’s library; collapse in 612 BCE.

segments.label: Neo-Babylonian Period
segments.note: Nabopolassar and Nebuchadnezzar II; Babylonian cultural revival; conquest of Jerusalem; fall to Persians.

segments.label: Achaemenid Period
segments.note: Babylon as Persian provincial center; preserved prestige; ends with Alexander’s conquest.
